message: We looked at the various commercial solutions, but they get incredibly expensive very quickly.

Currently, we're using Nagios configured by Puppet and some exported resources, but it's a bit too static for ep.io's ever-changing set of servers, so we might have to move to something slightly custom (but still using nagios plugins, no need to reimplement those).
We're actually using CloudKick, it's working well so far.  We're also running Munin just because it was easy to get set up with.

The last part of this presentation talks about Watchdog which looks like a pretty nice Python-based server monitoring and data-collection daemon. http://www.slideshare.net/ffunction/fabric-cuisine-and-watchdog-for-server-administration-in-python
@natea Given the code quality of Cuisine (I haven't looked at Watchdog) too I would be very wary of using that for something important.
@coderanger I hadn't looked at the code yet, only the presentation. Thanks for letting me know your take on it.
@andrewgodwin @ericflo we're evaluating Reconnoiter (https://labs.omniti.com/labs/reconnoiter) which has fault detection and trending. It's seeing a lot of active development right now.
We use collectd for monitoring (and looking at linking it to Graphite possibly for ad-hoc visualization) and a mix of collectd's alerting and some custom scripts the read the collectd data.
@natea Interesting, hadn't seen that. Seems the site suffers from the same poor documentation of "what does it do, exactly" that everywhere else does, however.
Also, I'm wary of even installing PHP on servers these days, though we do at least have a separate monitoring server.
@andrewgodwin yeah, sucks that the front-end is written in PHP. opens up a whole bunch of potential security threats. isolating it to a separate monitoring server is the way to go.
Only PHP app I'll go near now is Ganglia, and always run that on a separate server. It's far too useful not to have around.
@audreyr Wow, thats saying something given the labyrinth of awful that is Nagios configs :-P
We use Nagios on a separate monitoring server. I tried CloudKick but found Nagios config files easier to deal with.
By comparison, we didn't use CloudKick because of how much it costs.
I don't like cloudkick because it's too ready to throw away data except on the high end plans. And that data is gold for capacity planning.
